title: What is the meaning behind the song “Imagine” by John Lennon? - Quora

response.answer_text: This song is one of the most widely misunderstood songs in modern times, although that misunderstanding is understandable. :) The opening lines are: Imagine there’s no Heaven, it’s easy if you try, No Hell below us, above us only sky… If you take these lines at face value, they sound like a direct attack on what Christians, and many Jews and Muslims, believe. Therefore, it struck a number of people as an Atheist Anthem, disparaging all religion. In truth, it is not that. Imagine does not reject God as such, or Jesus or Mohammed for that matter; Imagine tries to persuade us to be on guard against the things that divide and separate us. The real, lasting concepts in religion—the things that Jesus and Buddha actually taught—ought to bring us together, in Lennon’s view, not be a cause for war. When religions give us reasons to hate each other or fight each other, they become toxic to the human race. The same thing, in Lennon’s mind, can be said about the political entities (countries and nations) that separate us, along with the borders that politicians and military leaders draw up. In the spirit of Imagine, we might ask: Who drew up these borders, anyway? Who is to say that one group of people have the God-given right to live on one side of a wall… and another group does not have that right? Are we not all members of the same species? In the end, Imagine is about envisioning a world in which more things bring us together than separate us. Lennon tells us that we may not seem to live in such a world now… but by picturing it, we might begin to bring it into existence.

“Imagine there’s no countries” - at the time he was having trouble getting a Visa to live in the US, partly due to his previous heroin addiction and possibly due to an alleged tip off by Elvis to Nixon, that he was bad news.“Imagine no possessions” - he was pissed off at having to pay a relatively small amount of alimony (£30k per year in today's money) for his son. To be fair he had recently bought Tittenhurst Park mansion and the upkeep was quite pricey.So, whilst its meant that every boring hippy with an acoustic guitar could virtue signal their self-righteousness (or as McCartney sang at the time ‘preaching back’) as he hinted at in interviews “Its about me…. again!”. It seems to be a similar pattern with his other ‘message’ songs : The Word “spread the word love”) and All You Need is Love were written whilst his first marriage was failingGive Peace a Chance was written when he was arguing over money with McCartney and the press over how Yoko was being portrayedPower to the People was written when he was feeling powerless during the legal case over Apple.It’s often true that those who shout the loudest are normally compensating for something.
